text:
Here’s how I chose a fitness watch for a typical person and why I’m selecting one to buy now.

Primary decision criteria (and why)
- Reliability and accuracy: prioritized established brands plus rating quality (score and review count) because accurate tracking and a dependable app matter most long term.
- Core features for everyday fitness: built‑in GPS, 24/7 heart rate, sleep tracking; these cover walking/running, gym, and daily wellness without being overly specialized.
- Battery life and display/readability: longer battery reduces charging friction; a clear display improves usability.
- Value for money: balanced price vs. capability and long‑term support.

How each available product stacked up
- Garmin vívoactive 5, Health and Fitness GPS Smartwatch, AMOLED Display, Up to 11 Days of Battery, Black — $220.89, 4.4 (5,567)
  - Strong all‑rounder: GPS, AMOLED, long battery, robust Garmin ecosystem. Slightly higher price but balanced feature set.
- Fitbit Versa 4 Fitness Smartwatch with Daily Readiness, GPS, 24/7 Heart Rate, 40+ Exercise Modes, Sleep Tracking and more, Waterfall Blue/Platinum — $149.95, 4.3 (14,803)
  - Great value and very popular; good features. Battery details not listed here, and some advanced insights on Fitbits may require a subscription (not shown on this page).
- Fitbit Inspire 3 Health & Fitness‑Tracker… — $79.95, 4.3 (18,574) [Only 4 left]
  - Excellent budget band, but it’s a slim tracker rather than a full smartwatch experience.
- Smart Watch (Answer/Make Call), 1.91"… — $24.99, 4.9 (563) [Overall Pick]
  - Extremely inexpensive with calling, but unknown brand and relatively low review count; long‑term reliability and data accuracy are unclear.
- WHOOP — 12‑Month Membership — 5.0 Health and Fitness Wearable — $359.00, 3.5 (47)
  - Subscription-centric and expensive; better for enthusiasts than a typical user.
- Fitness Tracker with 24/7 Heart Rate… — $28.99, 4.2 (135) [Sponsored]
  - Budget unknown brand; fewer reviews and uncertain app/ecosystem.
- Garmin Forerunner 55, GPS Running Watch… — $166.40, 4.6 (4,241)
  - Excellent rating and battery; focused on running (daily suggested workouts). Fewer general smartwatch features highlighted here than vívoactive 5.
- Smart Watch with Alexa Built‑in, 1.83"… — $29.99, 4.9 (430) [Sponsored]
  - Very low price and unknown brand; review base is smaller and long‑term support unclear.

Why I chose the Garmin vívoactive 5
- Best balance for a typical user: It pairs strong reliability (Garmin brand, solid 4.4 rating with 5,567 reviews) with a bright AMOLED display and up to 11 days of battery life—meaning better day‑to‑day usability than many watches.
- Broad fitness coverage without being niche: Built‑in GPS, health/fitness tracking, and smartwatch features make it versatile for walking, gym, cycling, and everyday wear, unlike the runner‑centric Forerunner 55 or the slim Fitbit Inspire 3 band.
- Value vs. capability: While pricier than the Versa 4, the vívoactive 5 offers longer stated battery and a premium display, and avoids the uncertainty of budget unknown brands.

Assumptions I made
- You want a full smartwatch (not just a thin band) with reliable tracking, readable display, and good battery.
- You’re not looking for a subscription‑centric device or a niche running watch.
- No strict budget was specified; mid‑range value is acceptable for long‑term use.

Limitations from the screenshot
- Not all specs are visible (water resistance ratings, phone compatibility, NFC/payments, advanced health sensors, and whether any features require subscriptions). I prioritized brand reputation, ratings, battery, and the clearly listed features.

I’ll add the Garmin vívoactive 5 to your cart now.
